title: Skills-Based Summary: AI Prompting from Concept to Application
text:
Missed the workshop? This guide distils the core prompting skills into digestible summaries. Each skill is presented as a conceptual foundation (2 sentences) plus pointers to deeper resources. Think of this as your ‚Äúcheat sheet for AI competence.‚Äù




Conceptual Summary: C.R.A.F.T. is a structured framework for clarity‚ÄîContext (background), Role (what perspective should AI take), Action (what do you want it to do), Format (how should output be structured), and Tone/Target (who‚Äôs the audience). The underlying principle: clear input produces clear output, and most disappointing AI results come from vague prompts, not AI limitations.
Why it matters: Prompting isn‚Äôt magic‚Äîit‚Äôs communication. A 30-second investment in clarity saves 10 minutes of revision.
Go deeper: C.R.A.F.T. Prompting Framework




Conceptual Summary: Rather than guessing how AI might help you, use AI as a diagnostic tool‚Äîhave it interview you about your role, challenges, and context, then it recommends both obvious and non-obvious applications tailored specifically to you. This meta-skill (using AI to teach you how to use AI) is uniquely powerful because AI can adapt to your specific situation in ways generic advice cannot.
Why it matters: You already know your work better than anyone. Let AI help you surface possibilities you would find valuable, not generic suggestions.
Go deeper: Using AI to Help You Use AI




Conceptual Summary: Beyond CRAFT, there are discipline-specific techniques proven to work in educational contexts: asking AI to role-play pedagogical scenarios, building scaffolded questions that match Bloom‚Äôs Taxonomy, using AI as a ‚Äúthought partner‚Äù for course design, having it simulate student misconceptions, and more. These aren‚Äôt random tricks‚Äîthey‚Äôre grounded in learning science and pedagogy.
Why it matters: Different contexts need different approaches. Knowing multiple techniques lets you choose the right tool for your teaching challenge.
Go deeper: Seven Essential Prompt Techniques for Business Teaching




Conceptual Summary: Long conversations have limits‚ÄîAI attention fades, hallucination risk increases, and output tokens get divided among multiple asks. The solution: break complex projects into focused sub-tasks, use separate conversations for different topics, and ask AI to summarize progress before starting fresh. Context management isn‚Äôt optional; it‚Äôs the difference between shallow and deep outputs.
Why it matters: A 5-minute conversation about one thing beats a 50-exchange conversation trying to do everything. Better outputs, fewer errors, clearer thinking.
Go deeper: Managing Context with AI




Conceptual Summary: Once you master basic prompting, you can ask AI to take on complex roles: simulating difficult student conversations, generating assessment rubrics and test items, role-playing stakeholder meetings, or even designing interactive learning simulations. These aren‚Äôt harder prompts‚Äîthey‚Äôre skilled applications of CRAFT and context management where you‚Äôre asking AI to perform a specific pedagogical function.
Why it matters: AI becomes most valuable when you stop treating it as a text-generation tool and start using it as a pedagogical instrument‚Äîa simulator, evaluator, or learning partner.
Applications: - Assessment design: ‚ÄúYou are an assessment specialist. Design a rubric for evaluating student critical thinking. Here are my learning outcomes: [paste].‚Äù - Simulation: ‚ÄúYou are a difficult student. I‚Äôll present my unit redesign; you ask challenging questions.‚Äù - Scenario planning: ‚ÄúYou are a department chair. I‚Äôm proposing this teaching change. What concerns would you raise?‚Äù
Go deeper: AI in Pedagogical Design & Delivery | Cognitive Prompting in Education




Conceptual Summary: The magic happens when you chain prompts: first generate ideas, then refine them, then adapt for different audiences, then format for delivery. A teaching strategy that emerges from dialogue (not one-shot generation) is higher quality and more personally aligned. The workflow is: explore ‚Üí review ‚Üí refine ‚Üí adapt ‚Üí finalise.
Why it matters: One conversation rarely produces a finished document. Iterative dialogue‚Äîwhere you provide feedback after each step‚Äîproduces outputs that actually match what you need.
Example workflow: 1. Explore: ‚ÄúWhat are 5 ways to integrate AI without replacing authentic student work?‚Äù 2. Review: ‚ÄúI like option 3. Tell me more about implementation.‚Äù 3. Refine: ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs good, but make it feasible for a class of 80.‚Äù 4. Adapt: ‚ÄúNow turn this into a 1-page faculty handout.‚Äù 5. Finalise: ‚ÄúGreat. Make it more encouraging and less technical.‚Äù
Go deeper: Prompt Chaining Techniques




Conceptual Summary: The bleeding edge includes AI agents (multi-step autonomous systems that solve problems without human intervention between steps), prompt automation (tools that run complex prompt chains without you typing each step), and emerging capabilities like real-time data access, image generation, and code execution. These aren‚Äôt essential for most educators, but they‚Äôre the horizon‚Äîunderstanding what‚Äôs possible helps you think strategically about future integration.
Why it matters: The AI landscape changes quarterly. Staying aware of emerging tools and approaches means you‚Äôre not caught off-guard when new capabilities arrive, and you can evaluate them thoughtfully rather than reactively.
Emerging areas to watch: - Agentic workflows: AI systems that plan, execute, and evaluate their own work - Multi-modal prompting: Combining text, images, audio, and code in single prompts - Custom knowledge bases: Uploading your own documents so AI learns your context - Real-time data: AI access to current information (weather, news, institutional databases) - Integration with learning platforms: AI embedded directly in your LMS
Current resources: - References & Further Reading (research and emerging papers) - Industry blogs: OpenAI, Anthropic, Google DeepMind

All seven skills rest on one foundation: respecting AI‚Äôs strengths while working around its limitations.

AI is brilliant at pattern-matching and idea generation but needs human judgment to verify facts and evaluate fit.
AI works best with clear, focused asks, not vague multi-part requests.
AI improves dramatically through iteration and feedback, not through hoping the first output is perfect.
AI is a tool for your thinking, not a replacement for it.

The skills above aren‚Äôt about becoming an AI expert. They‚Äôre about becoming proficient in a tool that increasingly matters for your work‚Äîmuch like email or spreadsheets before it.

You don‚Äôt need to master all seven skills to be effective with AI. Most educators find Skill 1 (CRAFT) and Skill 5 (Sophisticated Applications) cover 80% of their use cases.
But understanding all seven gives you flexibility: you can diagnose what‚Äôs not working, choose the right approach for the task at hand, and think strategically about where AI fits in your teaching and professional life.

title: What is AI? A Non-Technical Introduction
text:
Artificial Intelligence (AI) is software that can perform tasks that typically require human intelligence.
That‚Äôs it. No magic. No consciousness. Just software that can do things that used to require a human brain.


When we say ‚Äúintelligence,‚Äù we mean things like:

Recognizing patterns - ‚ÄúThis photo contains a dog‚Äù
Making decisions - ‚ÄúApprove this loan application‚Äù
Understanding language - ‚ÄúThe customer is asking about returns‚Äù
Predicting outcomes - ‚ÄúThis customer will probably buy this product‚Äù
Generating content - ‚ÄúWrite a summary of this report‚Äù

AI doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúthink‚Äù the way humans do. It processes data using mathematical patterns. But the results can look remarkably intelligent.




AI isn‚Äôt new. The term was coined in 1956. So why is everyone talking about it now?
Three things converged:



Every click, purchase, photo, search creates data
Companies now have billions of examples to learn from
Example: Netflix has billions of viewing decisions to learn what you might like





What took a supercomputer in 2000 now runs on a phone
Cloud computing made massive processing power accessible
Example: Training an AI model that would have cost $1M in 2010 now costs $100





New mathematical techniques (like ‚Äúdeep learning‚Äù) work better
Researchers figured out how to make AI learn from examples
Example: GPT (the technology behind ChatGPT) was invented in 2017

Result: AI that was science fiction 10 years ago is now practical and affordable.




AI isn‚Äôt one thing. It‚Äôs a family of different technologies, each good at different tasks.


How it works: Programmers write explicit rules
Example:
IF customer spent >$500 in last month
AND customer has no late payments
THEN offer premium membership
Good for:

Clear, logical decisions
Situations where rules don‚Äôt change
Compliance and regulations

Limitations:

Can‚Äôt handle exceptions or nuance
Breaks when faced with unexpected situations
Requires programmers to think of every scenario

Real-world use: Tax software, simple chatbots, spam filters (old-school)



How it works: Show the AI thousands of examples, and it figures out patterns
Example: You don‚Äôt program rules for ‚Äúwhat is a cat?‚Äù Instead:

Show it 10,000 photos labeled ‚Äúcat‚Äù
Show it 10,000 photos labeled ‚Äúnot cat‚Äù
It learns: ‚ÄúCats have pointy ears, whiskers, this shape‚Ä¶‚Äù

Good for:

Pattern recognition (images, sounds, behaviour)
Predictions based on past data
Problems where rules are too complex to write

Limitations:

Needs lots of examples to learn from
Only as good as the data you give it
Can‚Äôt explain why it made a decision

Real-world use:

Fraud detection (learning patterns of fraudulent transactions)
Product recommendations (learning what people who bought X also bought)

title: C.R.A.F.T. Prompting Framework
text:
The C.R.A.F.T. framework is a practical, structured approach to writing better prompts for AI tools.

Getting started? If you‚Äôre new to AI or unsure where to begin, consider starting with ‚ÄúUsing AI to Help You Use AI‚Äù first. That meta-skill will help you discover your own starting point, and then CRAFT becomes a powerful tool for structuring the prompts you actually need.

Whether you‚Äôre an educator, researcher, or professional staff member, CRAFT helps you communicate clearly with AI and get more relevant, high-quality results.
Most disappointing AI outputs result from vague or context-free prompts. The good news? Structured prompts produce dramatically better results with less rework.

Think of prompting like briefing a colleague: The better you brief the AI, the better its draft.





The framework has five elements. You don‚Äôt need to use all of them every time, but they provide a useful scaffold:









Letter
Element
What It Means
Example




C
Context
What‚Äôs the background? What data or situation are we working with?
‚ÄúThis is student enrolment data from business units over three semesters.‚Äù


R
Role
What role should the AI take on?
‚ÄúYou are an experienced teaching coordinator.‚Äù


A
Action
What specifically should the AI do?
‚ÄúAnalyse trends and identify units at risk.‚Äù


F
Format
How should the output be structured?
‚ÄúProvide results as bullet points.‚Äù


T
Tone/Target
What tone, and who‚Äôs the audience?
‚ÄúUse clear language suitable for faculty meetings.‚Äù








Clarity: Removes ambiguity from what you‚Äôre asking
Consistency: Works across all AI tools (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, Gemini, etc.)
Quality: Reduces rework by 30‚Äì50% in most cases
Speed: Takes just a few extra seconds to set up
Collaboration: Frames AI as a thinking partner, not just a tool





Important: CRAFT is one framework among many. Different prompting techniques work better for different people and different tasks. There‚Äôs no single ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù way to prompt AI.
Some educators and professionals find CRAFT helpful and structured. Others prefer simpler, more conversational approaches. The goal is clarity‚Äînot adherence to a framework.


1. Ask for step-by-step thinking Instead of asking for a final answer, ask the AI to walk through its reasoning first: > ‚ÄúBefore answering, walk me through how you‚Äôd approach this problem. Then provide your recommendation.‚Äù
2. Request explicit reasoning Ask the AI to show its work: > ‚ÄúExplain your thinking before providing the assessment rubric.‚Äù > ‚ÄúHow did you arrive at that conclusion?‚Äù
3. Provide good and bad examples Show the AI what you want (and what you don‚Äôt): > ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs an example of a good discussion question: [example]. Here‚Äôs a weak one: [bad example]. Now create three questions in the style of the good example.‚Äù
4. Use comparative framing Ask the AI to compare or contrast: > ‚ÄúShow me three different ways to explain this concept. What are the trade-offs of each?‚Äù
5. Break tasks into explicit steps Similar to prompt chaining, but simpler: > ‚ÄúFirst, summarise this. Then identify problems. Finally, suggest solutions.‚Äù
6. Ask for constraints Tell the AI what matters: > ‚ÄúKeep this under 150 words. Make it suitable for high school students. Use simple language.‚Äù
7. Request revision and refinement Most first drafts improve with feedback: > ‚ÄúThat‚Äôs a good start. Now make it more concise / more detailed / more critical / more encouraging.‚Äù





The best approach is the one that: - Makes sense to you (you understand why you‚Äôre structuring the prompt that way) - Works for your context (some frameworks fit teaching, others fit analysis) - Gets consistent results (you can repeat it and improve it)
Some people love the CRAFT framework. Others find it overly formal. Some prefer conversational, exploratory prompting. Others prefer ultra-specific, constraint-based prompting.
Try different techniques and notice what works: - Does CRAFT help you think through what you need? - Or do you prefer just asking clearly and iterating? - Do you like step-by-step structure, or does it feel rigid? - Do examples help you, or do you work better with descriptions?
There‚Äôs no ‚Äúwrong‚Äù answer‚Äîjust what works for your brain and your context.




Whatever technique you use, the underlying principle is the same:

Help the AI understand what you actually want.

Whether you do that through CRAFT, through examples, through step-by-step instructions, or through something else entirely‚Äîthe goal is clarity. If your current approach isn‚Äôt getting good results, try something different.
No framework is universal. CRAFT happens to be structured and teachable, which is why we highlight it. But your own conversational style, combined with iteration, is often just as effective.






Weak Prompt: > ‚ÄúHow can I use AI in my class?‚Äù
CRAFT-Improved Prompt: > ‚ÄúI teach first-year business students in a capstone project unit. You are an instructional designer. Suggest three practical ways to integrate AI tools without replacing authentic student work. Format as a bulleted list with implementation tips. Use language suitable for sharing with faculty colleagues.‚Äù
Why it‚Äôs better: - Context: We know the student level, discipline, and unit type - Role: AI knows what perspective to take (instructional designer) - Action: Clear, specific request (three ways, with implementation) - Format: Structured output (bullets + tips) - Tone: Colleague-appropriate language




Weak Prompt: > ‚ÄúAnalyse this data.‚Äù
CRAFT-Improved Prompt: > ‚ÄúThis CSV contains survey responses from 200 educators about AI adoption barriers. You are a research analyst. Identify the top 5 themes and frequency for each. Flag any surprising or contradictory patterns. Output as a structured summary with key quotes. Keep language technical but accessible for a research paper methods section.‚Äù
Why it‚Äôs better: - Context: Dataset size, content, source - Role: Research analyst (appropriate perspective) - Action: Specific analyses (themes, frequencies, contradictions, quotes) - Format: Structured summary - Tone: Suitable for academic writing




Weak Prompt: > ‚ÄúSummarise this compliance document.‚Äù
CRAFT-Improved Prompt: > ‚ÄúThis is a TEQSA compliance framework document. You are a senior teaching support officer. Extract the three most critical requirements for our business faculty. Highlight any compliance gaps we might have. Format as a one-page summary with clear action items. Use plain English suitable for a faculty board update.‚Äù
Why it‚Äôs better: - Context: Document type and regulatory body - Role: TSO (operational expertise) - Action: Extract + identify gaps + recommend actions - Format: One-page, action-oriented - Tone: Board-appropriate





Here‚Äôs something important: One-shot prompts tend toward sameness and averageness. When you ask AI a single question and take the first answer, you get polished, predictable, middle-of-the-road output. That‚Äôs not because AI is limited‚Äîit‚Äôs because you haven‚Äôt had a conversation yet.
The real exploration happens in the follow-up prompts. That‚Äôs where you push thinking deeper, challenge assumptions, ask for nuance, and steer toward your specific context and needs.

Think of AI prompting like a conversation with a capable colleague, not like asking a search engine for an answer.




First answers are drafts, not final thoughts. AI hasn‚Äôt yet understood your actual needs, constraints, or what matters to you.
Follow-ups reveal depth. ‚ÄúWhat am I missing?‚Äù or ‚ÄúNow dig deeper on that second point‚Äù pushes AI toward more thoughtful output.
You shape the thinking through dialogue. Each question you ask steers the conversation in new directions.
Specificity emerges through iteration. Vague initial responses become sharp and contextual through rounds of back-and-forth.
Your expertise guides the exploration. You know your discipline, your students, your institution. AI should adapt to that, not the other way around.




One-shot prompt (what many people do): > ‚ÄúHow can I use AI in my teaching?‚Äù
Output: Generic, average, 3‚Äì4 safe suggestions that apply to everyone

Conversational approach (what actually works):
Prompt 1 (CRAFT starting point): > ‚ÄúI teach business ethics to 2nd-year students. You are a pedagogy expert. What are 3 ways to use AI that deepen ethical thinking rather than replacing it? Include one activity for each. Format for colleague discussion.‚Äù
Output: Reasonable, but still somewhat generic
Prompt 2 (Follow-up - push toward depth): > ‚ÄúThose are helpful. The third one about ‚ÄòAI bias analysis‚Äô‚Äîthat‚Äôs interesting. Can you walk me through what a student would actually do in that activity? What would the AI‚Äôs role be, what would the student‚Äôs role be, and how would you know if they‚Äôre thinking critically versus just using AI?‚Äù
Output: Much more specific. You‚Äôre now co-designing the activity.
Prompt 3 (Follow-up - address your specific concern): > ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs my real worry: won‚Äôt students just copy what the AI says instead of forming their own ethical positions? How would you redesign this to force genuine student thinking?‚Äù
Output: Now AI is addressing your actual concern, not a hypothetical one.
Prompt 4 (Follow-up - make it practical): > ‚ÄúI like that. Now create a rubric I could actually use to grade this. What would ‚Äòdemonstrates genuine ethical reasoning‚Äô look like versus ‚Äòused AI as a crutch‚Äô? Make it specific enough that I can show it to students.‚Äù
Output: Practical tool, directly usable in your classroom.
Prompt 5 (Follow-up - iterate toward refinement): > ‚ÄúGood rubric. But I think ‚ÄòExcellent‚Äô is too hard to achieve. Can you adjust the criteria so that most engaged students could reach ‚ÄòProficient‚Äô? I don‚Äôt want to discourage them.‚Äù
Output: Refined rubric that matches your teaching philosophy.





One-shot: Generic advice, moderate usefulness, minimal iteration
Conversation: Specific to your context, increasingly useful, deeply refined

text:
This toolkit is a companion to the AI in Pedagogical Design and Delivery workshop. It extends Activity 3 ‚Äì 5‚ÄëStep Critique Framework with business‚Äëfocused questions and a few practical templates you can reuse in units, workplace activities, or assessments.

Using AI in business is like hiring a brilliant but inexperienced consultant: fast, confident, and sometimes dangerously wrong.
Without critique skills, you risk:

Overcomplicated solutions that no one has time or budget to implement
Missing legal, technical, or risk issues that create real exposure
Recommendations that sound good but don‚Äôt fit your organisation
One‚Äësize‚Äëfits‚Äëall advice that ignores culture, capacity, and constraints

Across HR, finance, marketing, supply chain, information systems, and management, the pattern is the same: uncritical AI acceptance can lead to poor decisions, reputational damage, compliance failures, and wasted resources.
Your professional edge is not ‚Äúusing AI‚Äù but reviewing, questioning, and improving what AI gives you.




This toolkit aligns with the workshop‚Äôs 5‚Äëstep model (Purpose, Plausibility, Evidence, Stakes, Action). Here is a more business‚Äëspecific lens you can use with any AI‚Äëgenerated recommendation, policy, plan, or analysis.

Comprehension Check ‚Äì Do I actually understand this?

Red flags: vague jargon, unclear rationale, no clear problem statement.

Ask:

‚ÄúExplain this in plain English for a non‚Äëexpert.‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat specific problem does this solve, and how?‚Äù

‚ÄúBreak this into concrete steps or actions.‚Äù


Simplicity Check ‚Äì Is this practical where I work?

Red flags: requires extra staff, expensive tools, or complex new processes.

Ask:

‚ÄúWhat is the minimum viable version of this?‚Äù

‚ÄúRewrite this for a small team with limited budget and time.‚Äù

‚ÄúShow a phased version over 3‚Äì6 months, not all at once.‚Äù


Legal, Technical & Risk Check ‚Äì What are the implications?

Red flags: no mention of compliance, privacy, security, fairness, or risk.

Ask:

‚ÄúWhat legal, regulatory, or policy issues could this raise?‚Äù

‚ÄúWhat are the main operational and reputational risks?‚Äù

‚ÄúWho could be harmed or disadvantaged by this recommendation?‚Äù


Context Check ‚Äì What assumptions is AI making about my organisation?

Red flags: assumes advanced systems, high trust, high skill, or unlimited capacity.

Ask:

title: AI in Pedagogical Design and Delivery
text:
The integration of Artificial Intelligence in Education (AIED) is fundamentally reshaping pedagogy. This overview outlines the five key areas of impact, from the core technology and its effect on course design and delivery to the critical challenges and the re-humanization of the educator‚Äôs role
The following five topics successfully organise the discussion across the technology itself (ITS), the impact on professional roles (The Architect, The Practitioner), the systemic obstacles (Challenges & Limitations), and the resulting transformation of the human professional (The Evolving Role of the Educator).


Key Takeaway: ITS deliver personalised, one-on-one instruction by relying on an integrated architecture of four key components: the Domain Model (what is taught), the Learner Model (who is learning, including successes and misconceptions), the Tutoring Model (how to teach), and the User Interface Model (interaction). The quality of instruction is directly determined by the sophistication of these underlying models, which collectively ensure that the system adjusts the pace, difficulty, and focus of lessons in real-time.
Analogy: Intelligent Tutoring Systems function much like an automated personal trainer at a gym. Just as the trainer analyzes your current fitness level, pace, and weaknesses (the Student Model), knows the curriculum of exercises (the Domain Model), and determines the optimal routine to challenge you without overwhelming you (the Tutoring Model), the ITS continuously adjusts the learning path to ensure instruction is both challenging and achievable, promoting deeper understanding.



Key Takeaway: AI fundamentally transforms the pedagogical designer‚Äôs role from a manual content creator to a Strategic Architect by automating previously slow and tedious tasks, such as generating course outlines, assessments, and multimedia. This automation forces the designer to focus on high-level, human-centric design‚Äîcreating flexible, dynamic frameworks and addressing emotional barriers to learning, rather than formatting slides or writing quiz questions.
Analogy: If traditional pedagogical design was like crafting a single, hand-built ship (a static course) that everyone had to sail on, the AI era redesigns the role of the architect. The new Pedagogical Architect now designs a complex, adaptive fleet where each ship (module) can adjust its sails, speed, and navigation (difficulty, pace, content) based on the real-time weather (student performance data), ensuring everyone reaches their destination, but along a personalised route. The architect‚Äôs most critical new job is ensuring the human crew (teachers and students) still communicate and build rapport, not just follow the automated navigation system.



Key Takeaway: AI revolutionizes pedagogical delivery by collapsing the feedback loop and providing educators with real-time data insights into student progress, performance patterns, and cognitive states. This data-driven delivery allows the human teacher to transition into a ‚Äúreal-time interventionist,‚Äù enabling them to abandon content presentation to the ‚Äúaverage‚Äù student and instead focus on targeted, high-value interventions based on immediate, actionable data. It can be viewed the impact of AI on pedagogical delivery not as a replacement for the teacher, but as an augmented reality for the classroom. AI handles the mechanics of instruction and data analysis, allowing the human practitioner to execute their craft with surgical precision, focusing their limited time on high-value, empathetic, and complex human interactions.
Analogy:. AI in the classroom functions as an AI Co-Pilot. The AI (co-pilot) handles the routine mechanics of flight (content delivery, system monitoring, and performance tracking), allowing the human pilot (the educator) to focus on complex navigation, communicating with the crew (students), and managing unexpected turbulence (misconceptions or emotional barriers) with surgical precision.



Key Takeaway: Despite the technological promise, a critical challenge for AIED is the risk of eroding the human element and exacerbating educational inequity through algorithmic bias. Over-reliance on ITS can reduce valuable face-to-face interactions, while studies show that students using AI sometimes feel less connected to their teachers (the ‚Äúparadox of connection‚Äù). Furthermore, predictive models trained on historical data risk perpetuating existing biases against marginalized groups when allocating resources or flagging ‚Äúat-risk‚Äù learners.
Analogy: Think of AIED as a new, highly efficient Automated Factory. While it produces learning materials at scale (efficiency), it risks creating a sterile, one-size-fits-all product that lacks the ‚Äúhuman touch‚Äù (eroding connection). More dangerously, if the factory‚Äôs blueprints (the algorithm) have a flaw (bias), it doesn‚Äôt just create one bad product; it replicates that flaw thousands of times, perpetuating the inequity at scale.



Key Takeaway: The long-term impact of AI is a forced re-humanization of the educator‚Äôs role, where the practitioner is compelled to abandon the commoditized, technical tasks (which AI can perform) and focus on the Human Edge of AI. This means prioritizing empathy, creativity, strategic thinking, mentorship, and socio-emotional support‚Äîthe unique human skills vital for holistic student development that AI fundamentally cannot replicate. Educators must also become proficient in interpreting AI data and developing ethical reasoning to guide responsible technology use.
Analogy: The integration of AI is like a Rising Tide. As the AI ‚Äútide‚Äù rises, it automates and submerges all the routine, technical ‚Äúlowlands‚Äù of the job (grading, content delivery). This forces the educator to move to the ‚Äúhigh ground‚Äù‚Äîthe uniquely human skills of empathy, mentorship, and creative problem-solving that the tide cannot reach. Their value is no longer in the submerged tasks, but on this new, more human-centric high ground.

text:
This handout supports the AI in Pedagogical Design and Delivery workshop. It is a concise, practical companion to Activity 5 ‚Äì Secure, Safe, and Sustainable AI and the broader integrity discussion.

title: Ethics, Data Governance & Integrity
text:
2.1 Transparency (Not Prohibition)
Principle: Make AI use explicit and assessable rather than hidden and policed.
In practice:

State clearly when AI is expected, permitted, or not permitted
Provide example prompts and tools yourself (e.g.¬†enterprise Copilot)
Assess how students use and critique AI, not whether they avoid it
Reward students who identify and correct AI‚Äôs errors and limitations

Why it helps integrity: When AI use is transparent, students learn to talk openly about their tools and reasoning. When it is simply banned, they are pushed toward secret, uncritical use.

title: Ethics, Data Governance & Integrity
text:
2.2 Critical Oversight (Not Blind Reliance)
Principle: AI is a tool that requires human judgement, not an authority to trust.
In practice:

Design tasks where students must critique, correct, or override AI outputs
Ask students to show what AI got wrong or missed
Grade the quality of their critique and improvement, not the AI‚Äôs first answer
Show real examples of hallucination, bias, oversimplification, or wrong jurisdiction

Why it helps integrity: Thoughtful use is harder than avoidance. Students practice professional habits of checking context, evidence, and consequences before acting on AI recommendations.

title: Ethics, Data Governance & Integrity
text:
2.3 Professional Relevance (Not Academic Abstraction)
Principle: Connect AI use in coursework to how AI is used in real workplaces.
In practice:

Frame tasks as professional scenarios (‚ÄúYou are the HR manager using AI to draft a policy ‚Ä¶‚Äù)
Discuss workplace ethics and accountability (Who is responsible when AI is wrong?)
Make AI literacy and responsible use visible in learning outcomes

Why it helps integrity: Students see AI not as a shortcut around academic work, but as a tool they must learn to handle responsibly in their careers.

title: Ethics, Data Governance & Integrity
text:
3.1 Enterprise vs Consumer Tools (Simple View)

Enterprise / approved tools (e.g.¬†MS Copilot Enterprise):

Data is siloed within the institution
Not used to train public models
Covered by institutional privacy and governance settings
Appropriate for course materials, assessments, and other non-public data

Consumer / free tools (e.g.¬†ChatGPT free, public web interfaces):

Conversations may be retained and used to improve services
Less transparent data handling
No institutional contract or guarantees
Risky for student work, unpublished materials, or any sensitive data

title: Ethics, Data Governance & Integrity
text:
3.2 Design Strategies for Safer Assignments
Instead of trying to ban tools you cannot see, design tasks that naturally encourage better data handling:

Use fictional or generic cases when detailed real data is not needed
Require de‚Äëidentification before any real data is used with AI
Ask for process documentation (key prompts, decisions) rather than full transcripts
Be explicit about which tools are recommended and why

course materials, assessment tasks, or realistic case data. Copilot keeps

text:
Before diving into the seven techniques, you might find it helpful to understand the C.R.A.F.T. Prompting Framework‚Äîa structured approach to writing clear, effective prompts in general.
The seven techniques in this guide are pedagogical prompts (teaching techniques you use with students). C.R.A.F.T. is a prompting methodology (how to write better prompts overall).
They complement each other: - Use C.R.A.F.T. to structure how you ask the AI to generate student prompts - Use these Seven Techniques to choose which type of prompt helps students develop specific skills
For example, when creating a Reverse Prompting exercise (Technique 1), you‚Äôd use C.R.A.F.T. to write clearer instructions to the AI about what kind of questions to generate.

These aren‚Äôt random AI tricks. These are seven proven prompting techniques specifically chosen because they develop critical thinking skills that business professionals across all disciplines need:

Pros and Cons ‚Üí Builds analytical decision-making skills
Stepwise Chain of Thought ‚Üí Reinforces process adherence and documentation

Each technique is easy to adapt and can be used by students directly or by you to generate teaching materials. Let‚Äôs explore each one with ready-to-use examples.






Instead of the student immediately solving a problem, the AI asks them questions to help scope out all the requirements, considerations, and potential issues. This mirrors real HR work, where defining the problem properly is half the battle.



Complex problem scoping is fundamental to all business disciplines. This technique forces students to move beyond obvious surface issues and consider the full complexity before starting to solve.

Instead of the student immediately solving a problem, the AI asks them questions to help scope out all the requirements, considerations, and potential issues. This mirrors real HR work, where defining the problem properly is half the battle.



Complex problem scoping is fundamental to all business disciplines. Whether designing policies, strategies, systems, or solutions, professionals must think through multiple stakeholders, constraints, legal/ethical implications, and trade-offs. This technique forces students to move beyond obvious surface issues and consider the full complexity before starting to solve.

The AI systematically analyzes multiple approaches to a business problem, evaluating each option against specific criteria. This develops the ability to make justified recommendations rather than just stating preferences.



All business professionals must evaluate competing strategies and make balanced, evidence-based recommendations. This technique builds the muscle for weighing trade-offs, considering multiple stakeholder perspectives, and justifying strategic choices.



What are the main models for conducting performance reviews in a hybrid

- Impact on employee morale and development

The AI will identify 3-4 performance review models (e.g., annual reviews, continuous feedback, 360-degree feedback, OKR-based systems) and analyse each systematically. The student receives a structured comparison that they must then critically evaluate.

title: Seven Essential Prompt Techniques for Business Teaching
text:
The AI walks through a complex business process one step at a time, pausing after each step until the student signals they‚Äôre ready to continue. This slows down high-stakes processes that students often rush through.



Many professional processes are legally, ethically, or operationally sensitive. Students need to understand why each step exists and what considerations apply at that stage. This technique forces deliberate, sequential thinking and deep engagement with process logic.



I am learning how to properly conduct a disciplinary action process for an
employee with a pattern of repeated lateness.

Your task: Walk me through the entire disciplinary process, starting from
the very first informal conversation. For each step, tell me:

1. What action to take
2. What to document
3. What legal or procedural consideration is important at this stage

After you explain each step, STOP and wait for me to type "next" before
moving to the next step. Do not provide the entire process at once.

Begin with Step 1.



The AI will provide the first step:

Step 1: Informal Verbal Warning
Action: Meet privately with the employee to discuss the lateness pattern. Use a calm, non-accusatory tone. Ask if there are any circumstances contributing to the issue (e.g., transport problems, personal issues, health concerns).
Documentation: Make a brief file note recording the date, what was discussed, and the employee‚Äôs response. This is informal, so no formal warning letter yet.
Legal/Procedural Consideration: At this stage, you‚Äôre gathering information and providing an opportunity for the employee to explain. Under principles of procedural fairness, you must give them a chance to be heard before escalating.
Type ‚Äúnext‚Äù when you‚Äôre ready for Step 2.

The student must actively engage with each step before progressing. This prevents them from skipping to ‚Äújust fire them‚Äù without understanding the required process.

text:
The AI adopts a specific persona and engages in a realistic conversation with the student. This is the ‚Äúflight simulator‚Äù concept in action.



Business work is fundamentally about interaction‚Äîwith clients, stakeholders, teams, and colleagues. Students can memorize theory, but until they practice actually having difficult conversations where others push back, get emotional, or raise objections, they won‚Äôt develop genuine interpersonal competence.



You are an experienced and empathetic HR Business Partner. I am a new,
nervous manager who needs to put one of my team members on a Performance
Improvement Plan (PIP).

Your goal is to coach me through preparing for and conducting this meeting
successfully.

Guide me through this step by step:
1. First, ask me why the employee is being put on a PIP
2. Wait for my answer
3. If my answer is vague or subjective (e.g., "bad attitude"), challenge me
   gently and ask me to be more specific and behavioural
4. Once I give you a solid answer, move to the next aspect: helping me
   draft clear, measurable objectives for the PIP
5. Continue coaching me through each element of the conversation I need to
   have with the employee

Throughout this process, if I say something that could be problematic
(legally risky, unfair, too harsh, or too vague), pause and give me
feedback on how to improve it.

Begin by asking me your first question.



The AI becomes a coach who actively guides the student through preparation. If the student says ‚ÄúI‚Äôm putting them on a PIP because they‚Äôre lazy,‚Äù the AI will respond:

‚ÄúI understand you‚Äôre frustrated, but ‚Äòlazy‚Äô is subjective and not something we can measure or document defensibly. Let‚Äôs try again: what specific behaviours or performance gaps have you observed? For example, are they missing deadlines, producing work below the required standard, or not completing their assigned tasks?‚Äù

This iterative coaching helps students learn to think and speak like HR professionals.

title: Seven Essential Prompt Techniques for Business Teaching
text:
The AI examines multiple perspectives on a contentious issue, argues for and against different positions, and helps students see the complexity and trade-offs in strategic decisions.



Modern business work exists in gray areas where competing legitimate perspectives exist. Whether addressing HR challenges, business strategy, operational trade-offs, financial decisions, or policy questions, professionals need to develop the ability to argue multiple sides of an issue before making a defensible recommendation.



I will provide you with two different "Bring Your Own Device (BYOD)"
policies from two fictional companies.

Your task:
1. Critique the strengths and weaknesses of each policy in terms of
   security, employee privacy, and clarity
2. Tell me which policy is stronger overall and why
3. Identify one element from the weaker policy that could improve the
   stronger one

Here is Policy A: [paste policy]
Here is Policy B: [paste policy]

Begin your analysis.
Teaching use: You draft two policies (or have the AI generate them), one deliberately flawed. Students must identify which is better and justify their reasoning. This develops critical evaluation skills.



I want you to debate the pros and cons of using AI-powered tools to scan
resumes and filter job applicants.

Structure your response in three parts:

**Part 1: The Case FOR Using AI Resume Screening**
Make the strongest possible argument in favour of this technology. Consider
efficiency, consistency, potential to reduce human bias, cost savings, and
scalability.

**Part 2: The Case AGAINST Using AI Resume Screening**
Make the strongest possible argument against this technology. Consider
algorithmic bias, legal risk, lack of contextual understanding, potential
discrimination, and dehumanization of the recruitment process.

**Part 3: Critical Synthesis**
Critique both arguments you just made. What did each side get right? What
did each side oversimplify or ignore? Provide a balanced recommendation
with conditions (e.g., "Use AI screening only if X, Y, and Z safeguards
are in place").
What Happens: The AI will construct sophisticated arguments for both positions, then provide a nuanced synthesis. Students can‚Äôt just pick a side‚Äîthey have to understand the legitimate concerns and benefits on both sides.



This is the most sophisticated version:
You will simulate a leadership debate on whether to implement a "mandatory
return to office" policy requiring all employees to work in-office four
days per week.

Create three distinct personas and have them debate this issue:

**Persona 1: The CFO (Chief Financial Officer)**
Focus on: Real estate costs, productivity metrics, and financial efficiency

**Persona 2: The CHRO (Chief HR Officer)**
Focus on: Employee morale, retention, recruitment competitiveness, and
diversity/equity/inclusion implications

**Persona 3: The COO (Chief Operating Officer)**
Focus on: Team collaboration, operational consistency, training
effectiveness, and company culture

Have each persona make their opening argument (3-4 sentences each). Then
have them respond to each other's points. Continue the debate through three
rounds until they need to make a recommendation to the CEO.

After the debate, summarize the key tension points and what a compromise
policy might look like.

Begin the debate.
What Happens: The AI will create a realistic executive debate where each stakeholder has legitimate but competing priorities. Students see that there‚Äôs rarely a perfect answer‚Äîonly trade-offs and compromise.



After reading the debate, students must: 1. Identify which stakeholder made the strongest argument and why 2. Propose a policy that addresses the COO‚Äôs concerns while minimising the CHRO‚Äôs risks 3. Explain what data or evidence would help resolve the CFO‚Äôs questions 4. Reflect on which psychological or organisational theory best explains the tension between these perspectives



This technique is perfect for preparing students for case study exams. Instead of memorizing model answers, they practice analysing competing priorities and justifying nuanced positions‚Äîexactly what they‚Äôll need to do in professional practice.

title: Seven Essential Prompt Techniques for Business Teaching
text:
The AI generates unlimited practice questions, scenarios, or quizzes that students can use to test their knowledge and build confidence. This provides low-stakes repetition and immediate feedback‚Äîessential for skill development.



Many HR competencies require both knowledge (legislation, theory) and application (recognizing situations where that knowledge applies). Students need more practice than traditional homework provides, but creating dozens of unique practice scenarios is time-prohibitive for lecturers. AI solves this.



Student Prompt:
I'm studying for an exam on Australian employment law. I need to practice
identifying which legislation applies in different workplace scenarios.

Generate 10 short scenario descriptions (2-3 sentences each) where I need
to identify:
1. Which legislation is relevant (e.g., Fair Work Act, WHS Act,
   Anti-Discrimination Act)
2. What the employer's legal obligation is
3. What risk exists if the employer doesn't comply

After I answer each one, tell me if I'm correct and explain why.

Begin with Scenario 1.
What Happens: The AI creates scenario after scenario. Students test themselves, get immediate feedback, and can continue until they achieve mastery. Unlike a textbook with 5 practice problems, this provides unlimited practice.
Key feature: AI adapts. If student gets several wrong, AI can simplify. If student masters basic scenarios, AI can make them more complex.




Student Prompt:
I'm learning to identify different types of workplace conflict (task
conflict, relationship conflict, process conflict).

Create 8 brief workplace scenarios. For each one, I'll identify the type
of conflict and suggest an appropriate intervention approach.

After each scenario, provide feedback on my classification and intervention
suggestion. If I'm wrong, explain why and what I missed.

Make the scenarios progressively more complex‚Äîstart easy, end with
ambiguous situations where multiple interpretations are valid.

Begin with Scenario 1.
What Happens: Progressive difficulty builds confidence and competence. Students move from obvious cases to nuanced judgment calls.




Student Prompt:
Create a practice exam for me based on the topics we've covered in my
Workplace Conflict Resolution unit.

Include:
- 10 multiple choice questions (4 options each)
- 3 short-answer questions (each requiring 150-200 word response)
- 1 case study with 4 analysis questions

Topics to cover:
- Conflict theory (Thomas-Kilmann, interest-based bargaining)
- Investigation processes
- Mediation approaches
- Legal requirements (procedural fairness, natural justice)

After I complete the exam, grade my answers and provide detailed feedback
on what I got right/wrong and why.
What Happens: Students can generate multiple practice exams with different questions each time. They enter the real exam having practiced extensively.




Lecturer Prompt (to create remediation resource):
I have students who struggled with understanding procedural fairness in
workplace investigations. Many think it just means "being nice" and don't
understand the specific legal requirements.

Create a 10-question diagnostic quiz that tests whether students understand:
1. The right to be informed of allegations
2. The right to respond to allegations
3. The requirement for impartial decision-making
4. The requirement to consider the response before deciding
5. The right to representation/support

For each question, use a scenario format. After each answer, provide
immediate teaching feedback explaining the principle, not just whether
they're right or wrong.

Generate the quiz.
What You Get: A targeted remediation tool that teaches while testing. Students who failed your assessment can use this to identify and fix their knowledge gaps.




Option 1: Recommended Practice (Ungraded)
In your unit outline: > ‚ÄúBefore each assessment, I recommend using AI to generate practice questions and scenarios. Spend 30-60 minutes testing yourself until you feel confident. This is optional but strongly encouraged.‚Äù
Option 2: Required Pre-Assessment Activity (Low Stakes)

‚ÄúBefore the Week 8 exam, complete a self-generated practice test (minimum 20 questions). Submit a screenshot showing completion and a 100-word reflection: What did you learn from this practice? What areas do you still need to review?‚Äù

Worth 5% of final grade‚Äîgraded on completion and reflection quality, not on how many they got right.
Option 3: Study Group Activity

‚ÄúIn your study groups, use AI to generate practice scenarios. Each person generates 5 scenarios and tests the group. Discuss answers and explanations together.‚Äù

Combines AI efficiency with peer learning.




Important: This technique is for practice, not for graded assessment.
Why? - Students can regenerate until they get ‚Äúgood‚Äù questions they already know answers to - AI-generated questions lack the rigor of carefully designed exam questions - Students need to struggle and make mistakes in low-stakes practice
The value: Unlimited, personalised practice that builds confidence and competence before high-stakes assessment.




Advanced Student Prompt:
I want to practice identifying workplace bullying vs. performance management
vs. legitimate reasonable management action.

Create scenarios for me to classify. After each one:
- If I get it right, make the next scenario more nuanced and ambiguous
- If I get it wrong, make the next scenario clearer and more obvious
- Continue until I can correctly identify 5 difficult/ambiguous cases in a row

Track my progress and tell me when I've achieved mastery.

Begin.
This creates a personalised learning path‚ÄîAI adjusts difficulty based on student performance.




Traditional practice is limited by: - Finite textbook questions - Lecturer time to create practice materials - Inability to provide immediate feedback at scale
AI removes these constraints: - Infinite practice scenarios - Instant generation - Immediate feedback - Adaptive difficulty
Result: Students can practice until they achieve mastery, not until they run out of practice problems.




While true adaptive AI systems require technical infrastructure, students can manually create adaptive difficulty through smart prompting:
Student Prompt: Self-Directed Progression
I want to practice identifying workplace bullying vs. legitimate performance
management vs. reasonable management action.

Generate scenarios for me to classify. After I answer each one, tell me if
I'm correct.

Track my performance. When I get 8 out of 10 correct, automatically make
the next batch of scenarios more complex and ambiguous. When I get fewer
than 5 out of 10 correct, make the next batch clearer and more obvious.

Continue until I can correctly identify 5 difficult, ambiguous cases in a row.

Begin with Scenario 1 at medium difficulty.
What This Achieves: - Student-controlled difficulty progression - Mastery-based advancement - Builds confidence through appropriate challenge - No technical setup required‚Äîjust good prompting
Teaching Tip:
Encourage students to track their progress: > ‚ÄúBefore your next exam, use AI to practice until you achieve 90% accuracy on hard scenarios. Submit a screenshot showing your progression and a 100-word reflection on what you learned.‚Äù
This creates accountability without requiring sophisticated adaptive systems.

Students consult multiple AI ‚Äúexperts‚Äù with different theoretical or professional perspectives on the same HR problem, then synthesize the competing advice into a strategic recommendation.



HR problems rarely have single ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù answers. They exist at the intersection of psychology, law, business strategy, and ethics. This technique forces students to consider legitimate but competing perspectives and make informed choices about priorities and trade-offs.



I need to address high turnover in our sales department (35% annual turnover;
industry average is 18%). This is affecting team morale, increasing
recruitment costs, and impacting customer relationships.

Create three expert personas who will each analyse this problem from their
professional perspective:

**Expert 1: Organisational Psychologist**
Focus on: Employee motivation, job satisfaction, workplace culture, team
dynamics, psychological contracts

**Expert 2: Compensation & Benefits Specialist**
Focus on: Pay equity, market competitiveness, incentive structures, total
rewards, cost-benefit analysis

**Expert 3: Talent Management Strategist**
Focus on: Career development, succession planning, retention programs,
employee value proposition, organisational capability

Have each expert independently provide:
1. Their diagnosis of why turnover is high (from their perspective)
2. Their recommended intervention strategy
3. Potential risks or limitations of their recommended approach
4. What data they would need to validate their hypothesis

After all three experts have provided their analysis, I will synthesize
their recommendations and develop my own strategic recommendation.

Begin with Expert 1: Organisational Psychologist.



The AI creates three distinct voices:
Organizational Psychologist: > ‚ÄúThe 35% turnover suggests a breakdown in psychological contract or poor person-organization fit. Sales roles are inherently stressful, but this level suggests systemic issues‚Äîpossibly unrealistic targets, poor management relationships, or lack of autonomy. I recommend: (1) Conduct stay/exit interview analysis focusing on psychological factors, (2) Assess manager-employee relationship quality, (3) Review goal-setting processes‚Ä¶‚Äù
Compensation Specialist: > ‚ÄúAt 35% turnover, you‚Äôre likely seeing pay inequity or uncompetitive base/commission structures. Sales talent is mobile and market-driven. I recommend: (1) Conduct compensation benchmarking against competitors, (2) Analyse pay dispersion within the team, (3) Review commission structures for fairness and achievability‚Ä¶‚Äù
Talent Management Strategist: > ‚ÄúHigh turnover in sales suggests limited growth opportunities or unclear career paths. Top performers leave when they plateau. I recommend: (1) Map career progression pathways, (2) Implement mentoring for high-potentials, (3) Create lateral development opportunities‚Ä¶‚Äù



After receiving all three perspectives, students must:

Compare and Contrast:

Where do the experts agree?
Where do they conflict?
Which diagnosis seems most plausible given the evidence?

Synthesize:

‚ÄúIf I could only implement one intervention, which would have the most impact?‚Äù
‚ÄúHow could I combine elements from multiple recommendations?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs the minimum viable intervention that addresses multiple root causes?‚Äù

Justify with Theory:

‚ÄúWhich HR theory best explains my chosen approach?‚Äù (e.g., Herzberg‚Äôs two-factor theory, social exchange theory, expectancy theory)
‚ÄúWhat evidence would I need to collect to validate my choice?‚Äù

Acknowledge Trade-offs:

‚ÄúWhat am I deprioritizing by choosing this approach?‚Äù
‚ÄúWhat are the risks if my diagnosis is wrong?‚Äù





Variation 1: Policy Design
Three experts debate a proposed "Bring Your Own Device" policy:
- IT Security Officer (focus: data protection, cybersecurity)
- HR Manager (focus: employee experience, equity, privacy)
- CFO (focus: cost savings, business case, ROI)

Each argues for their priorities. Student must design a policy that
balances all three perspectives.
Variation 2: Ethical Dilemma
Three experts analyse whether to implement mandatory return-to-office:
- Employee Relations Specialist (focus: morale, retention, fairness)
- Operations Manager (focus: productivity, collaboration, efficiency)
- Legal Counsel (focus: contractual obligations, discrimination risk, WHS)

Student must recommend a policy that is ethical, legal, and operationally sound.
Variation 3: Change Management
Three experts advise on implementing AI resume screening:
- Diversity & Inclusion Officer (focus: algorithmic bias, equity)
- Recruitment Lead (focus: efficiency, candidate experience)
- Risk & Compliance Manager (focus: legal compliance, audit trails)

Student must design an implementation plan that addresses all concerns.



Assignment: Multi-Expert Consultation Report
Student Requirements: 1. Generate consultation with 3 experts on an assigned HR problem 2. Submit full transcript of expert advice 3. Write 1000-word synthesis report including: - Summary of each expert‚Äôs position - Analysis of agreements and conflicts - Your strategic recommendation with justification - Theoretical framework supporting your choice - Implementation risks and mitigation strategies
What You‚Äôre Assessing: - Ability to understand multiple valid perspectives - Synthesis and integration skills - Strategic decision-making under ambiguity - Application of HR theory to justify choices - Recognition of trade-offs and constraints



Most business teaching presents one ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù approach. But professional practice requires navigating competing legitimate perspectives.
This technique teaches: - No single expert has the complete answer - Good business decisions balance multiple priorities and perspectives - Strategic thinking means choosing which perspective to prioritize when - Justification matters more than the specific choice - Real problems require synthesis, not just analysis



Expert Panel works brilliantly with:
Pros and Cons (Technique 2): > ‚ÄúAfter consulting the expert panel, use the Pros and Cons technique to evaluate each expert‚Äôs recommended intervention systematically.‚Äù
Debating (Technique 5): > ‚ÄúHave the three experts debate each other‚Äôs recommendations. Then you arbitrate and make the final decision.‚Äù
Role Play (Technique 4): > ‚ÄúAfter developing your strategy based on expert consultation, role-play presenting it to a skeptical stakeholder (CFO, union rep, CEO) and defend your choices.‚Äù

title: Teaching with AI: From Passive Users to Critical Partners
text:
Welcome


‚ÄúGood afternoon, everyone. My name is Dr.¬†Michael Borck, and I‚Äôm a lecturer in Business Information Systems.
Today, I want to share an innovative assessment I‚Äôve been developing that tries to answer a question many of us are grappling with: How do we authentically assess our students in a world that is being fundamentally reshaped by Generative AI?‚Äù



The Context: An Industry in Motion


‚ÄúMy work is at the intersection of machine learning and business. What I‚Äôm seeing, and what our industry partners are telling us, is that GenAI is driving incredible change.
The core premise I build from is this: these tools aren‚Äôt replacing our graduates. They are amplifying their skills. A good analyst with AI support can outperform a great analyst without it.
This presents a clear challenge for us as educators. If this is the new reality of the professional world, we have an obligation to prepare our students for it. We need to move beyond simply ‚Äòbanning‚Äô it and instead teach them how to leverage it effectively.‚Äù

My work focuses on the intersection of machine learning and business.
Our industry is evolving at an incredible pace, driven by GenAI.
Core Premise: These tools are not replacing professional skills; they are amplifying them.
The Question: If our industry is using these tools, how can we not teach our students to use them effectively, critically, and responsibly?




The Challenge: Assessing with AI


‚ÄúThis leads us to the central challenge. The old model of trying to ‚Äòcatch‚Äô students using AI feels like a losing battle, and I‚Äôm not sure it‚Äôs the right one to fight.
The reality is, our students will use these tools, just as professionals in the field are now required to.
So, the goal of my assessment design was to shift the focus. I don‚Äôt want to just assess what they know; I want to assess how they think and work with AI.
This requires a move towards ‚ÄòLane 2‚Äô or open assessments, where we design tasks that explicitly build skills like effective prompting, critical evaluation of AI output, and the ability to refine and take full responsibility for the final product.‚Äù

The Old Model: ‚ÄúCatching‚Äù students using AI. (Is this productive?)
The New Reality: Students will use AI. Professionals must use AI.
The Goal: Shift from assessing what students know to how they think and work with these new tools.
The Need: An assessment that teaches and tests the new critical skills:

Effective prompting (intelligence gathering).
Critical evaluation (separating fact from hallucination).
Refinement and integration (taking responsibility as the author).





The Assessment: The ‚ÄòCloudCore‚Äô Audit


‚ÄúThis led me to design a new assessment for my postgraduate information security unit.
I call it the ‚ÄòCloudCore Audit.‚Äô It‚Äôs a Lane 2, open assessment where students are immersed in a real-world scenario. Their task is to conduct a full security audit of a simulated AI company called CloudCore.
What makes this innovative, and the focus of my talk, is its two-pronged approach to AI integration.
First, students interact with AI-powered characters who act as the client. Second, they are encouraged to work with an LLM of their choice as their personal assistant.‚Äù

Unit: Postgraduate Information Security.
Task: Conduct a comprehensive information security audit of ‚ÄòCloudCore‚Äô, a simulated AI-based company.
Two-Pronged AI Integration:

Students interact with AI (as the client).
Students work with AI (as an assistant).





Innovation 1: AI as the ‚ÄúClient‚Äù


(‚Äú‚Ä¶students don‚Äôt just get static documents. They interact with AI chatbots‚Ä¶ For example, the CFO chatbot‚Ä¶‚Äù), you can have the GIF silently looping on the slide. It‚Äôs the ideal ‚Äúshow, don‚Äôt just tell‚Äù moment.
‚ÄúLet‚Äôs look at that first prong. When a consultant starts a real audit, they don‚Äôt get a neat package of all the information. They have to interview people.
To simulate this, students don‚Äôt just get static documents. They interact with AI chatbots who play the roles of key company employees.
For example, the CFO chatbot is programmed to think about budget and risk. ‚ÄòRaj,‚Äô the IT Manager, is focused on operational fires and his team‚Äôs bandwidth.
This immediately teaches a critical skill: how to gather intelligence. Students learn that the quality of their questions‚Äîtheir prompts‚Äîdirectly determines the quality of the answers. A vague question to the CFO gets a vague, ‚Äòbusiness-speak‚Äô answer. A specific question about risk tolerance for data breaches gets a much more useful, nuanced response.‚Äù

Students interact with AI chatbots role-playing as company employees.
Example Roles:

CFO: Focuses on budget, risk appetite, and compliance costs.
‚ÄòRaj‚Äô (IT Manager): Concerned with operational issues, technical debt, and team capacity.

The Skill: Teaches effective intelligence gathering.
The Feedback Loop: Better prompts yield more insightful, specific responses. Poor prompts get vague, unhelpful answers.




Innovation 2: AI as the ‚ÄúIntern‚Äù


‚ÄúThe second innovation is how we frame their use of tools like ChatGPT. I explicitly encourage them to use an LLM, but I frame it very specifically:
‚ÄòTreat the AI as your junior intern.‚Äô
This framing is powerful because it‚Äôs relatable. An intern can do a lot of heavy lifting. But you would never just copy-paste an intern‚Äôs draft straight into a final report for a client.
Why? Because the intern, like the AI, doesn‚Äôt have the full context. They haven‚Äôt sat through all the lectures or read all the material. They will guess to fill in the gaps, and as we all know, an LLM can be confidently wrong.
This reframes the student‚Äôs role immediately.‚Äù

Students are encouraged to use an LLM of their choice (e.g., ChatGPT, Claude).
The Framing is Crucial: ‚ÄúTreat the AI as a junior intern.‚Äù
What does this mean?

An intern is powerful and can do a lot of work fast.
An intern does not understand the full context of the assignment.
An intern will guess, and sometimes guess poorly or ‚Äúconfidently make things up‚Äù (hallucinate).

The Skill: Teaches critical evaluation and responsibility.




The Student as ‚ÄúAuthor‚Äù


‚ÄúThe ‚Äòintern‚Äô framing makes one thing crystal clear: the student is the author, and they are ultimately responsible for 100% of the final product.
The work they submit must reflect their own understanding. This shifts the entire conversation. It‚Äôs no longer about ‚Äòdid you use AI?‚Äô It‚Äôs about ‚Äòhow well did you manage your AI intern?‚Äô
This model requires them to use their knowledge from the course to critically evaluate the AI‚Äôs output, to tell when it‚Äôs helpful and when it‚Äôs hallucinating. They must review, edit, and stand by every single word.‚Äù

The ‚Äòintern‚Äô framing establishes a clear hierarchy of responsibility.
The Rule: ‚ÄúYou are the author. You are 100% responsible for the final product. Every word you submit must reflect your understanding.‚Äù
This moves the assessment from ‚ÄúDid you write this?‚Äù to ‚ÄúCan you defend this?‚Äù
It explicitly tests their ability to:

Use their course knowledge to evaluate the AI‚Äôs output.
Identify and correct errors.
Refine and add the necessary critical analysis.





Pedagogy: ‚ÄúThinking with AI‚Äù


‚ÄúUltimately, my goal is to teach students not just what to think, but how to think with AI.
And this assessment model makes the quality of that thinking visible.
My best students don‚Äôt use ‚Äòone-shot‚Äô prompts. They don‚Äôt just ask the AI to ‚Äòwrite an audit.‚Äô Instead, they have a conversation. They explore ideas, they refine concepts, they push back on the AI.
Many also do what a real professional would: they use multiple LLMs to cross-reference the findings. They‚Äôll ask their ‚Äòinterns‚Äô to debate each other. This is a massive step up from being a passive user.‚Äù

The goal is to teach students how to think with AI.
Low-Level Use (The ‚ÄòC‚Äô Student):

Uses ‚Äòone-shot‚Äô prompts.
Gets basic, generic results.
Submits a report that is superficial and easily identifiable.

High-Level Use (The ‚ÄòA‚Äô Student):

Has a conversation with the AI.
Explores ideas, refines concepts, asks ‚Äúwhat if.‚Äù
Uses multiple LLMs to cross-reference findings.
This mimics professional industry practice.





Design & Authenticity


‚ÄúMy main design priority is authenticity. It has to be as close to industry practice as possible.
In the real world, you don‚Äôt have 24/7 access to a client‚Äôs team. Access is scheduled, and frankly, it‚Äôs often unpredictable.
So, I‚Äôm already evolving this model. Instead of just having the chatbots available anytime, students will need to schedule specific appointments.
And to make it even more realistic, an AI ‚Äòemployee‚Äô might occasionally ‚Äòcancel‚Äô a meeting, forcing the student to adapt and reschedule. This isn‚Äôt about being difficult; it‚Äôs about teaching the logistical adaptability that is a very real part of any client engagement.‚Äù

Priority: The assessment must mirror industry practice.
In the real world, client access is not unlimited or 24/7. It‚Äôs scheduled and unpredictable.
The Next Evolution:

Scheduled Access: Students must schedule specific appointments with the AI employees (e.g., ‚ÄúThe CFO is only available on Tuesday afternoon‚Äù).
Simulating Unpredictability: An AI ‚Äòemployee‚Äô might occasionally cancel a meeting, forcing the student to reschedule.

The Skill: Teaches adaptability, planning, and managing logistical challenges‚Äîall key professional competencies.




Academic Integrity as Transparency


‚ÄúThis brings us to the big question: academic integrity.
My approach is to focus on transparency. I ask students to submit the transcripts of their conversations with their chosen LLM.
Crucially, this isn‚Äôt about ‚Äòcatching‚Äô them. It‚Äôs a teaching tool. It allows me to see their thought process.
A student who uses a basic, one-shot prompt will get a basic, generic result from the AI, and that is reflected in their audit and their grade.
But the transcripts also show me the students who are really thinking. I can see them pushing back on the AI, refining its output, and applying course concepts. This assessment model makes their process visible, and that process is what I‚Äôm trying to teach.‚Äù

How do we manage integrity in this model? By focusing on transparency.
I ask students to submit the transcripts of their conversations with their ‚Äúintern.‚Äù
This is a teaching tool, not a ‚Äúgotcha‚Äù tool.
It allows me to see their thought process.
I can see the student who used a basic prompt and got a basic result. Their grade reflects that superficial engagement.
I can also see the student who wrestled with the AI, refined its output, and demonstrated critical thought. Their grade reflects that deep engagement.




Key Takeaways


‚ÄúSo, to conclude, what are the key takeaways from this assessment design?
First, we should embrace GenAI as the amplifier it is.
Second, framing is critical. The ‚ÄòAI as Intern‚Äô model works because it empowers students but holds them accountable.
Third, by designing assessments that interact with AI and asking for transparency, we can start to assess the process of thinking, not just the final product.
Ultimately, our goal must be to prepare our students for the modern workplace. That means helping them move from being passive users of these tools to becoming active, critical partners with them.‚Äù

Embrace the ‚ÄúAmplifier‚Äù: GenAI is a tool that amplifies skills. Our assessments should reflect this.
Frame it Right: The ‚ÄúAI as Intern‚Äù model empowers students while enforcing their role as the responsible author.
Assess the Process: By making the process visible (via chatbots and transcripts), we can assess the how (critical thinking) and not just the what (the final product).
The Goal: Move students from passive users to active, critical partners with AI.




Thank You

Dr.¬†Michael Borck michael.borck@curtin.edu.au

‚ÄúThank you for your time. I‚Äôd be happy to answer any questions you have about the design, the implementation, or the student feedback so far.‚Äù

text:
One of the most underrated skills in working with AI is managing context‚Äîthe information you feed to an AI system and how you structure your conversations.
Think of context like the working memory of the AI. Unlike humans, who can maintain context across days or weeks of conversation, AI has specific limitations:

Limited attention span: Conversations have maximum lengths before older information gets ‚Äúforgotten‚Äù
Token limits: Every token (word fragment) used in conversation‚Äîboth input and output‚Äîcounts against the model‚Äôs capacity
Output token competition: When you ask an AI to do multiple things at once, it must divide its output tokens among all the tasks, often producing shallow results
Hallucination risk: As conversations grow longer, the risk of AI ‚Äúmaking up‚Äù information (hallucinating) increases

The good news? Understanding and managing context is a learnable skill that directly improves output quality, saves time, and reduces errors.






What happens: You have a great conversation going. You‚Äôve asked 15 follow-up questions, refined ideas, built on earlier outputs. Then you ask question 16, and AI gives you a response that contradicts something from question 3.
Why: The AI‚Äôs working memory is limited. While it can technically ‚Äúsee‚Äù the entire conversation, older information becomes less salient (less in focus) as the conversation grows. AI attention diminishes with distance.



What happens: You ask AI to ‚Äúredesign this unit, create a rubric, write student instructions, and design an assessment.‚Äù You get four things, but each is shallow because AI divided its output tokens four ways.
Why: Every model has a maximum output token limit (typically 1,000‚Äì4,000 tokens). If you ask for 4 things, you get roughly 250‚Äì1,000 tokens per thing. Quality suffers.



What happens: As conversations get longer, AI becomes more likely to ‚Äúconfidently generate false information‚Äù‚Äîfabricating citations, making up examples, or misremembering earlier statements.
Why: Longer conversations increase uncertainty and complexity in the model‚Äôs reasoning. It‚Äôs trying to track more information and making more inferential leaps.



What happens: You close the chat window. Next week, you want to continue the work. You paste your earlier thinking into a new chat, but AI doesn‚Äôt have the full conversation history, so it repeats earlier points or misses nuance.
Why: Each new conversation starts fresh. The AI has no memory of the previous session unless you explicitly provide it.





The Principle: Before diving into work, ask AI to help you structure the task.
Why it works: - Distributes output tokens efficiently (each step gets focus) - Reduces hallucination risk (smaller scope per prompt) - Gives you a plan to follow (more organised) - Lets you quality-check each step before moving forward


Instead of asking all at once: > ‚ÄúRedesign my unit on data literacy. Create new learning outcomes, design assessments, write student instructions, create a rubric, and draft a unit description.‚Äù
Break it into steps‚Äîfirst step, ask for a plan: > ‚ÄúI‚Äôm redesigning a unit on data literacy for 2nd-year business students. Help me create a structured plan for this redesign. What are the key steps I should follow? List them in order with what we should accomplish at each step.‚Äù
[AI gives you a plan: outcomes ‚Üí assessments ‚Üí instructions ‚Üí rubric ‚Üí description]
Then work through the plan one step at a time:
Step 1: > ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs start with step 1. Here are my current outcomes: [paste]. Which are clear and assessable? Which need work? Suggest 2‚Äì3 revised outcomes focused on authentic data literacy.‚Äù
[Get focused, high-quality outcomes]
Step 2: > ‚ÄúGood. Now for step 2: suggest three assessment approaches that would test those outcomes. For each, explain what students do and why it tests data literacy.‚Äù
[Get focused assessment options]
And so on.



Create a research plan first: > ‚ÄúI‚Äôm designing a study on student retention. Help me outline the key steps: research question, variables, methods, data collection, analysis, and writing. What‚Äôs the logical order? What questions should I answer in each phase?‚Äù
Then tackle one phase at a time: > ‚ÄúPhase 1: Research question. I‚Äôm interested in belonging, confidence, and persistence. Help me craft a specific research question that addresses these. Make it answerable.‚Äù

Why it works: - Each output gets full attention and token allocation - Quality increases (you get depth, not breadth) - Easier to review and iterate on one thing - Reduces the cognitive load on the model

Output: Shallow. Each element is skeletal.
Better: (One task per prompt)
Prompt 1: > ‚ÄúDesign 3 activities for teaching data visualization that move from basic to complex. For each, describe what students do and what they‚Äôll learn.‚Äù
Prompt 2 (after reviewing): > ‚ÄúNow create an assessment rubric for evaluating students‚Äô data visualizations. Include 4 criteria, with descriptions of excellent/proficient/developing for each.‚Äù
Prompt 3 (after reviewing): > ‚ÄúTurn that rubric and the activity descriptions into a one-page student handout. Include: what they‚Äôre learning, why it matters, the activities, success criteria, and how to get help.‚Äù
Output: Deep. Each element is thoughtful and specific.

Comparative tasks: ‚ÄúShow me 3 different ways to explain photosynthesis to 9th graders. What are the trade-offs of each?‚Äù
Structured formats: ‚ÄúCreate an outline with: learning outcomes, key concepts, and 2 discussion questions‚Äù

AI knows exactly how to divide tokens. Output is balanced and concise.

3. [Third thing] - [length/format]

The Principle: When a conversation gets long, ask AI to summarize what you‚Äôve accomplished, then start fresh in a new conversation.

[AI provides a summary]

Paste the summary at the beginning
Add: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm continuing this work. Let‚Äôs move forward with [next step].‚Äù
Continue from there

Here‚Äôs the context: [paste].‚Äù

(Missing: What is ‚Äúthis‚Äù? What‚Äôs the class? What‚Äôs the issue? What‚Äôs your teaching style?)
Good context: > ‚ÄúI teach critical thinking to 40 business students (mix of 2nd and 3rd year, variable engagement). One student dominates discussions while others stay quiet. How can I manage this without embarrassing the dominant student or discouraging the quiet ones?‚Äù

One challenge: one student always dominates. How can we structure the discussion activity to naturally encourage quieter students to speak?‚Äù



Who: Who are the students/audience?
What: What‚Äôs the specific task or problem?
Why: Why does it matter?
Constraints: What are the limitations (time, resources, class size)?

The Principle: When you have multiple similar tasks (e.g., ‚Äúwrite 5 discussion questions‚Äù), batch them efficiently.
Poor approach: > ‚ÄúWrite a discussion question on topic A.‚Äù > [Review] > ‚ÄúWrite a discussion question on topic B.‚Äù > [Review] > [Repeat 3 more times]
This takes 5+ exchanges and repeats setup context each time.
Better approach:
Prompt: > ‚ÄúI need 5 discussion questions for a unit on organisational leadership. They should:- Progress from basic understanding to critical analysis- Each take 5‚Äì10 minutes of discussion- Spark respectful debate (not yes/no questions): 1) Leadership styles, 2) Ethical decision-making, 3) Team conflict, 4) Change management, 5) Inclusive leadership.all 5 questions with a note about why each one works.‚Äù
Single exchange. AI understands the pattern. Higher quality.
Then iterate once: > ‚ÄúThese are good. Now adapt question 3 and 5 to be more accessible for international students who might be less familiar with Western leadership literature.‚Äù












Mistake
What Goes Wrong
Fix




Asking for 10 things at once
Output is shallow; tokens split 10 ways
Break into 2‚Äì3 prompts, one task per prompt


Vague task description
AI misunderstands what you want
Add explicit context: who, what, why, constraints


Leaving the conversation open indefinitely
Hallucination risk increases; conversation becomes unwieldy
Start new conversation every 30‚Äì50 exchanges


Not specifying output format
AI guesses format; may not match your needs
Say ‚Äúbullet points,‚Äù ‚Äú3 paragraphs,‚Äù ‚Äútable,‚Äù etc.


Asking ‚Äúwhat am I missing?‚Äù
AI may invent things that don‚Äôt apply
Be specific: ‚ÄúWhat am I missing for [specific context]?‚Äù

Errors and hallucinations slip through
Always quality-check, especially for facts/citations


Pasting entire documents without context
AI doesn‚Äôt know what you want it to focus on
Add a framing sentence: ‚ÄúHere‚Äôs my unit outline. Focus on the assessment section.‚Äù
