Ask AI for a plan before diving in
Break the plan into sub-tasks
Identify output tokens needed for each sub-task





One sub-task per prompt (usually)
Review each output before moving forward
Provide feedback for refinement
Document what works (save successful prompts)





Keep conversations focused (one major project per conversation)
When long, ask for a summary and move to a new conversation
Use separate conversations for different topics
Archive completed work (save or export as needed)





Verify facts (especially citations, dates, statistics)
Check for contradictions (does it align with earlier outputs?)
Assess completeness (did AI address all your needs?)
Iterate if needed (refine with follow-up prompts)






Scenario: Designing a 10-week research methods course.
Bad approach (what NOT to do): 1. ‚ÄúDesign the entire course including all 10 modules, learning outcomes, assessments, readings, activities, and rubrics.‚Äù 2. Get massive output that‚Äôs shallow and poorly integrated 3. Spend hours revising piecemeal
Good approach:
Conversation 1: Planning > ‚ÄúI‚Äôm designing a 10-week research methods course for master‚Äôs students in business. Help me create a modular plan. What are the key topics? How should they sequence? What should we accomplish each week?‚Äù
[Get: 10-week high-level plan with learning arcs]
Conversation 2: Learning Outcomes > ‚ÄúUsing the plan from earlier, let‚Äôs define learning outcomes. Here‚Äôs the plan: [paste]. For each week, suggest 1‚Äì2 specific, assessable outcomes. Focus on both knowledge and practical research skills.‚Äù
[Get: structured outcomes aligned to plan]
Conversation 3: Week 1 Deep Dive > ‚ÄúLet‚Äôs design Week 1 in detail. Topic: Research foundations. Learning outcomes: [paste from outcomes]. Design the week including: 2 key concepts to introduce, 1 activity, 1 short assessment, 3 readings. Keep it manageable for a 3-hour week.‚Äù
[Get: detailed, coherent week]
Conversation 4: Week 2 Deep Dive > ‚ÄúNow Week 2: [repeat with Week 2 focus]‚Äù
[Continue for each week if needed, or batch weeks by theme]
Conversation 5: Assessment & Integration > ‚ÄúI‚Äôve now designed all 10 weeks. Here‚Äôs a summary: [paste all 10-week outcomes + activities]. Design a capstone assessment that integrates learning from the whole course. What should students do? How would you evaluate it?‚Äù

Keep conversations focused: One major project per conversation
Be explicit with context: Don‚Äôt assume AI understands implicit information
Summarize and handoff: When conversations get long, reset with a summary

title: What are Large Language Models (LLMs)? A Non-Technical Introduction
text:
Reading time: 12 minutes
Prerequisites: Read ‚ÄúWhat is AI?‚Äù first for context



A Large Language Model (LLM) is AI trained to predict the next word in a sentence.
That‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs the core idea.
But from that simple task‚Äîpredicting the next word‚Äîthese models learned to:

Write essays, emails, code, and poetry
Answer questions about almost any topic
Translate languages
Summarize documents
Explain complex concepts
Hold conversations

Examples you‚Äôve probably heard of:

ChatGPT (OpenAI)
Claude (Anthropic) - what you might use in this masterclass
Gemini (Google)
Copilot (Microsoft)





This seems magical, but here‚Äôs the intuition:


Imagine you‚Äôre a child learning language. Someone shows you thousands of examples:
Example 1:
‚ÄúThe cat sat on the ___‚Äù ‚Üí You learn: ‚Äúmat‚Äù is likely (from seeing this pattern before)
Example 2:
‚ÄúI went to the store to buy ___‚Äù ‚Üí You learn: ‚Äúmilk,‚Äù ‚Äúbread,‚Äù ‚Äúgroceries‚Äù are likely (from context)
Example 3:
‚ÄúThe capital of France is ___‚Äù ‚Üí You learn: ‚ÄúParis‚Äù (you‚Äôve seen this fact stated before)
Example 4:
‚ÄúIf you drop a glass, it will ___‚Äù ‚Üí You learn: ‚Äúbreak‚Äù or ‚Äúshatter‚Äù (cause and effect)
Now multiply that by billions of examples from:

Wikipedia
Books
News articles
Websites
Code repositories
Academic papers
Reddit conversations
Social media

By learning to predict the next word, the AI absorbed:

Grammar and syntax (how language works)
Facts about the world (Paris is the capital of France)
Common sense (glass breaks when dropped)
How arguments are structured (how to explain things)
Different writing styles (formal, casual, technical, creative)






You know autocomplete on your phone?
Your phone suggests:
‚ÄúI‚Äôm running late, I‚Äôll ___‚Äù ‚Üí ‚Äúbe there soon‚Äù (common phrase)
An LLM is like that, but:

Trained on trillions of words (not just your texts)
Can predict entire paragraphs, not just one word
Can change style, tone, and complexity
Can incorporate context from earlier in the conversation

Example conversation:
You: ‚ÄúExplain photosynthesis‚Äù
LLM thinks:

Context: science topic, explanation needed
Style: educational but accessible
Structure: definition ‚Üí process ‚Üí significance
Next words likely: ‚ÄúPhotosynthesis is the process‚Ä¶‚Äù

LLM responds: ‚ÄúPhotosynthesis is the process by which plants convert sunlight into energy‚Ä¶‚Äù
It‚Äôs predicting what words would naturally come next in an explanation of photosynthesis based on millions of similar explanations it‚Äôs seen.






1. Huge Amount of Training Data

Trained on hundreds of billions of words
Equivalent to reading millions of books
Takes weeks/months to train

2. Massive Number of Parameters

‚ÄúParameters‚Äù = the patterns the model learned
GPT-3: 175 billion parameters
GPT-4: Rumored to be over 1 trillion parameters
Think of parameters as: ‚ÄúIn this context, this word is more likely than that word‚Äù

3. Enormous Computing Power

Training GPT-3 cost ~$4-12 million in computing
Required thousands of high-end processors
Months of continuous processing

Why does size matter? Bigger models:

Learn more subtle patterns
Handle more complex tasks
Generalize better to new situations
But: more expensive to train and run








What they‚Äôre good at:

Writing emails, reports, blog posts
Creating marketing copy
Drafting contracts and documents
Generating creative stories

Example business use: Customer service team uses LLM to draft responses:

Reads customer inquiry
Suggests a response in company style
Human reviews and sends
Result: 60% faster response times

Why it works: LLMs have seen millions of examples of professional writing in every style.




What they‚Äôre good at:

Summarizing long documents
Extracting key points from reports
Identifying themes in customer feedback
Creating executive summaries

Example business use: Legal team reviews 500-page contracts:

LLM summarizes key terms and risks
Highlights unusual clauses
Human lawyer reviews flagged items
Result: 70% time savings on initial review

Why it works: LLMs can process and condense large amounts of text while maintaining meaning.




What they‚Äôre good at:

Answering factual questions
Explaining complex topics simply
Providing step-by-step instructions
Troubleshooting common problems

Example business use: Internal knowledge base assistant:

Employees ask HR, IT, or policy questions
LLM searches knowledge base and synthesizes answer
Provides relevant links to full documentation
Result: 40% reduction in help desk tickets

Why it works: LLMs can find relevant information and explain it in natural language.




What they‚Äôre good at:

Translating between languages
Converting formal to casual tone (or vice versa)
Adapting content for different audiences
Restructuring information

Example business use: Global company communications:

Write announcement in English
LLM translates to 20 languages
Human native speakers review
Result: Faster, more consistent global communication

Why it works: LLMs understand structure and meaning, not just word-for-word translation.




What they‚Äôre good at:

Writing code from descriptions
Explaining what code does
Finding bugs
Suggesting improvements

Example business use: Analysts use LLM to write SQL queries:

Describe what data they need in plain English
LLM generates the SQL code
Analyst reviews and runs query
Result: Non-programmers can extract data

Why it works: Code is a language, and LLMs learn patterns in code like any other language.







The problem: LLMs can ‚Äúhallucinate‚Äù - confidently state false information
Example:
You ask: ‚ÄúWho won the 2024 Nobel Prize in Literature?‚Äù
LLM might say: ‚ÄúJane Smith for her novel ‚ÄòThe Silent Echo‚Äô‚Äù (completely made up)
Why it happens:

LLM is predicting plausible-sounding text
It doesn‚Äôt ‚Äúknow‚Äù facts, it predicts likely word patterns
If it doesn‚Äôt know, it guesses based on similar patterns

Lesson for business:

Don‚Äôt use LLMs for legal, medical, or financial advice without human verification
Do use LLMs to draft content that humans then verify
Do combine LLMs with verified databases (retrieval-augmented generation)





The problem: LLMs only know what was in their training data (usually cut off months/years ago)
Example: You ask: ‚ÄúWhat happened in the stock market today?‚Äù LLM: Can‚Äôt answer - its training data ended months ago
Why it happens:

Training happened at a specific point in time
The model is ‚Äúfrozen‚Äù after training
It can‚Äôt browse the internet or access current data (unless specifically connected to search)

Lesson for business: - ‚úó Don‚Äôt ask for current prices, stock quotes, weather, news - ‚úì Do connect LLM to real-time data sources (databases, APIs) - ‚úì Do use for tasks where current information isn‚Äôt critical




The problem: LLMs pattern-match; they don‚Äôt reason logically
Example:
You ask: ‚ÄúIf it takes 5 machines 5 minutes to make 5 widgets, how long does it take 100 machines to make 100 widgets?‚Äù
Common LLM mistake: ‚Äú100 minutes‚Äù (pattern-matching ‚Äú100 and 100‚Äù)
Correct answer: ‚Äú5 minutes‚Äù (requires logical thinking)
Why it happens:

LLMs predict plausible-sounding text based on patterns
They don‚Äôt actually ‚Äúthink through‚Äù problems step by step
Complex reasoning requires logic LLMs don‚Äôt truly have

Lesson for business:

Don‚Äôt use for complex calculations, logic puzzles, or critical reasoning
Do use for tasks where pattern recognition is enough
Do verify any logical claims the LLM makes





The problem: LLMs don‚Äôt remember past conversations (unless you‚Äôre in the same session)
Example:
Yesterday: ‚ÄúMy name is John and I work at RetailFlow‚Äù
Today: ‚ÄúWhat company do I work for?‚Äù
LLM: ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt have that information‚Äù
Why it happens:

Each conversation session is isolated
LLM has no persistent memory
It only knows what‚Äôs in the current conversation

Lesson for business:

Don‚Äôt expect LLM to remember previous interactions
Do provide context each time (‚ÄúI‚Äôm analysing RetailFlow‚Äôs customer data‚Ä¶‚Äù)
Do build systems that pass context to the LLM explicitly





The problem: LLMs remix and combine, but don‚Äôt have original insights
Example:
You ask: ‚ÄúInvent a revolutionary new business model‚Äù
LLM: Will suggest combinations of existing models, not truly novel ideas
Why it happens:

LLM can only recombine patterns it‚Äôs seen
Can‚Äôt have the ‚Äúeureka moment‚Äù of genuine innovation
Creativity looks like remixing existing ideas in new ways

Lesson for business:

Don‚Äôt expect breakthrough innovations or original strategies
Do use for brainstorming variations on existing ideas
Do use to explore possibilities you might not have considered








Common use: First-line chatbot for customer inquiries
How it works:

Customer asks question
LLM generates response based on knowledge base
Simple questions: LLM answers directly
Complex questions: Routes to human agent with context

Benefits:

24/7 availability
Instant responses to routine questions
Frees humans for complex issues

Challenges:

May give wrong information (hallucination risk)
Can‚Äôt handle frustrated or emotional customers as well
Needs regular monitoring and refinement

Success example: E-commerce company uses LLM for order tracking, returns, and product questions. 70% of inquiries resolved without human intervention. Customer satisfaction remained high (82%) for LLM-handled queries.




Common use: Drafting marketing copy, product descriptions, social media
How it works:

Marketing team provides brief and key points
LLM generates draft in brand voice
Human edits, refines, approves

Benefits:

5x faster content creation
Consistent brand voice
A/B testing multiple versions quickly

Challenges:

Generic output without human refinement
Needs clear brand guidelines and examples
Human oversight essential for quality

Success example: Retail company uses LLM to write product descriptions. Human provides: product specs, target audience, key benefits. LLM generates 100 descriptions in minutes. Human editors review and refine top candidates.




Common use: Internal Q&A system for company knowledge
How it works:

LLM trained on company documents, policies, procedures
Employees ask questions in natural language
LLM finds relevant information and explains it
Provides links to source documents

Benefits:

Faster onboarding
Reduced help desk load
Knowledge accessible to everyone

Challenges:

Keeping training data up-to-date
Ensuring accuracy of information
Integrating with existing systems

Success example: Tech company builds internal assistant trained on HR policies, IT procedures, and product documentation. New employees can ask questions 24/7. Reduced HR help desk tickets by 40%.




Common use: Helping analysts write SQL, Python, or Excel formulas
How it works:

Analyst describes what they need in plain English
LLM generates the code
Analyst reviews, tests, adjusts

Benefits:

Non-programmers can extract data
Faster analysis
Learning tool (see how LLM solves problems)

Challenges:

Generated code may have bugs
Security risks if code isn‚Äôt reviewed
May not follow company coding standards

Success example: Finance team uses LLM to generate SQL queries. Analysts describe what data they need, LLM writes query, analyst reviews and runs. Analysis time cut by 60%.




Common use: Summarizing, extracting information from documents
How it works:

Upload long document (contract, report, proposal)
LLM summarizes key points
Extracts specific information (dates, amounts, terms)
Human reviews summary and makes decisions

Benefits:

Process large volumes quickly
Consistent extraction format
Focus human time on decision-making

Challenges:

May miss subtle details
Needs verification for critical documents
Formatting issues with complex documents

Success example: Legal team processes 100+ contracts per week. LLM summarizes key terms, flags unusual clauses, extracts deadlines. Lawyers review summaries instead of full documents unless flagged. Time savings: 50%.

Better Solution
Why?

Traditional AI (simpler)
Clear categories, fast, cheaper

LLM
Needs natural language generation

Speed and precision critical, not language

Mitigation:

Risk: LLM reflects biases in training data
Example:

Hiring LLM trained on biased past data may discriminate

Mitigation:

The meta approach is more powerful because AI asks you clarifying questions first, learns your context, and then provides recommendations tailored to your actual situation‚Äînot generic advice for a hypothetical educator or professional.




Here‚Äôs a prompt you can use immediately. Copy it, paste it into your AI tool of choice (ChatGPT, Claude, Copilot, Gemini, etc.), and adapt it to your role:

AI doesn‚Äôt know anything about you initially. By asking sequential questions, it builds a comprehensive picture of: - Your discipline and teaching/research/operational context - Your students, colleagues, or stakeholders - Your constraints and resources - What success looks like for you

title: Teaching with AI: From Passive Users to Critical Partners
text:
In the context of Artificial Intelligence, the terms Black Swan and Grey Swan refer to how we categorize and prepare for risks. They are metaphors describing high-impact events based on how predictable they are.
Here is the breakdown of Black Swan vs.¬†Grey Swan events specifically within the AI landscape.

1. Black Swan Event
The Definition: A Black Swan event is an occurrence that is unpredictable, has a massive impact, and is often rationalized in hindsight (we look back and say, ‚Äúwe should have seen that coming,‚Äù even though we couldn‚Äôt have).
In AI, these are ‚Äúunknown unknowns.‚Äù They represent scenarios that are not in our training data, not in our risk models, and often fundamentally change the trajectory of the technology or society.

Key Characteristics:

Rarity: It is an outlier; nothing in the past points to its possibility.
Impact: Extreme consequences (catastrophic or revolutionary).
Retrospective Predictability: Explanations are concocted after the fact.


Examples in AI Context: * Emergent Capabilities: An AI model suddenly developing a capability it was never trained for and that developers did not believe was possible (e.g., a language model suddenly solving unsolved mathematical theorems without specific training). * The ‚ÄúFlash Crash‚Äù Scenario: Interconnected AI trading bots simultaneously hallucinating a market trend that doesn‚Äôt exist, crashing the global economy in seconds before humans can pull the plug. * Zero-Day Exploits: A novel AI-generated cyberattack that bypasses all known security protocols because it utilizes a logic path no human coder ever considered.



2. Grey Swan Event
The Definition: A Grey Swan event is predictable and known to be possible, but is considered unlikely to happen.
In AI, these are ‚Äúknown unknowns.‚Äù We know the risk exists, and we might even have a name for it, but we often ignore it or under-prepare because the probability seems low.

Key Characteristics:

Foreseeability: We know it could happen (it has precedents or is theoretically obvious).
Neglect: It is often dismissed as too expensive or complex to prevent.
Impact: Significant, often cascading through systems.


Examples in AI Context: * Infrastructure Collapse: A geopolitical conflict (e.g., in Taiwan) cutting off the supply of advanced GPUs (Nvidia chips), causing a sudden, long-term freeze in global AI development. We know this is a supply chain bottleneck, but the industry operates as if it won‚Äôt happen. * Legal/Copyright Shutdown: A supreme court ruling that declares all training on copyrighted data illegal, forcing major foundation models (like GPT-4 or Claude) to be deleted or retrained from scratch. This is a known legal risk that companies are currently ‚Äúbetting‚Äù against. * Data Poisoning: A coordinated attack where bad actors slowly feed ‚Äúpoisoned‚Äù data into open-source datasets over years, leading to a sudden, widespread failure of models that rely on that data.


Summary Comparison








Feature

Possible to mitigate, but often ignored due to cost/effort.


Analogy

A massive solar flare wiping out data centers.





Relevance to You (AI Facilitator)
As a lecturer and facilitator, you are likely helping students and colleagues think about Grey Swans (ethical frameworks, bias mitigation, legal compliance, institutional policies). However, the philosophical allure of AI often focuses on Black Swans (singularity, AGI, existential risk).
Distinguishing these helps people understand where to focus day‚Äëto‚Äëday design and governance efforts (mitigating Grey Swans) versus where they need more flexible, long‚Äëterm thinking (adapting to Black Swans). You can pair this note with the handout Ethics, Data Governance & Integrity when framing AI risk and Assessment 2030.
